docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments that they recommend for patients.

headline.main: Cost of Treatment May Influence Doctors
headline.print_headline: Treatment Cost Could Influence Doctors’ Advice

docs.abstract: Some of most influential medical groups in nation are recommending that doctors weigh costs, not just effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care; shift suggests doctors, who say they can no longer ignore rising prices of health care, are starting to redefine their roles, and could result in them choosing one drug over another for cost reasons.
docs.snippet: Some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments that they recommend for patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: While Congress is away, 2.3 million Americans are left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever act to renew unemployment benefits.

headline.main: No Spring Break for the Unemployed
headline.print_headline: No Spring Break for the Unemployed

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes Congress for delaying renewal of federal unemployment benefits, which expired at the end of 2013; contends Republicans bear most of the blame.
docs.snippet: While Congress is away, 2.3 million Americans are left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever act to renew unemployment benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: As more people use their local libraries to connect to the Internet, libraries are requesting funding for better services.
docs.abstract: Institute of Museum and Library Services says there is urgent need to equip public libraries nationwide with high-speed Internet service; 62 percent of libraries offer only free computer and Internet access in their communities, but only 9 percent say they have high-capacity connections.
docs.snippet: As more people use their local libraries to connect to the Internet, libraries are requesting funding for better services.

keywords.value: Institute of Museum and Library Services
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The wealthy face tax increases that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the superrich.

headline.main: Merely Rich and Superrich: The Tax Gap Is Narrowing
headline.print_headline: New Tax Takes Aim at Ranks of Superrich

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column notes that wealthy Americans face significant tax increases starting in 2013 that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the super-rich; says taxpayers reporting more than $10 million in income pay lower tax rates than do taxpayers reporting $500,000 to $10 million.
docs.snippet: The wealthy face tax increases that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the superrich.

docs.lead_paragraph: Profit declined 7.8 percent partly because of the health law and the high costs of a hepatitis C treatment.

headline.main: Health Law Bellwether, UnitedHealth Posts Lower Profit
headline.print_headline: Health Law Bellwether, Insurer Posts Lower Profit

docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group, federal health care law bellwether, reports first-quarter profit declined 7.8 percent partly because of the law and the high costs of a new drug to treat hepatitis C; earnings were $1.1 billion from $1.19 billion in year-ago quarter; revenue rose 4.5 percent to $31.71 billion.
docs.snippet: Profit declined 7.8 percent partly because of the health law and the high costs of a hepatitis C treatment.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults needed to maintain the plan’s viability.

headline.main: Enrollments Exceed Obama’s Target for Health Care Act
headline.print_headline: Signups Exceed Obama’s Goal for Health Act

docs.abstract: Pres Obama announces eight million people have signed up for health insurance under Affordable Care Act, including what White House says is sufficient number of young, healthy adults; critical milestone is reached that might counter election-year attacks by Republicans on law’s success and viability; critics caution that promising top-line numbers are not by themselves proof of success.
docs.snippet: Eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults needed to maintain the plan’s viability.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama mounted a vigorous effort on Thursday to show his signature healthcare law is working and dismissed Republican critics who are using flaws in Obamacare to campaign for ousting Democrats from the U.S. Congress in November.

headline.main: Obama Argues Healthcare Law Is Working, Rejects Republican Criticism
headline.print_headline: Obama Argues Healthcare Law Is Working, Rejects Republican Criticism

docs.abstract: Assessing yet another potential metric for the health care law’s success.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight million people have signed up for health care through new insurance exchanges and the proportion of younger applicants has increased, President Barack Obama said Thursday. The enrollments exceeded expectations and offered new hope to Democrats who are defending the law ahead of the midterm elections.

headline.main: Obama: 8 Million Signed Up for Health Care
headline.print_headline: Obama: 8 Million Signed Up for Health Care
